issue.title: CH09 feedbacks
issue.body:
```
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
data = [1, 5, 2, 3, 2]
df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['value'])
df
plt.bar(df.index, df.value) #pass x label value and y label value
```
The first line should be ```import pandas as pd``` because pyplot has already been imported before. However, pandas has not been imported.

Also, I think ```plt.show()```should be added to make sure the figure will be displayed

issue.title: Assignment 1-Data of different kinds pop up all at once in rows
issue.body:
# Troubleshooting
Different types of data (names, types, numbers of reviews, etc., as the website crawled is TripAdvisor) came up in one piece of text and in rows, stopping further attempts in ranking in rows with different columns showing different specs in cvs file. Also, irrelevant texts that should be in other parts of the site were included. Should be because of wrong coding/filtering in the previous steps but couldn't define which parts to be included.

## Describe your environment

* Operating system: MacOS 10.11.6
* Python version: 3.6.3
* Hardware: MBPR 13" 2015
* Internet access: Wi-Fi
* Jupyter notebook or not? [Y/N]:Y
* Which chapter of book?:Assignment

<!-- Texts appear in angle brackets like this are comments and will not show in your issue body. They are here to help you fill in this form. Feel free to remove those comments. You can also remove other texts that is irrelevant to your issue -->

## Describe your question
Where to look for the exact tags needed? How to ensure data came in different section to be written in columns instead of rows?

Example: I get IOError when running my script to load files.

<!-- Upload screenshot if it helps. Simply drag and drop the image in this editing window. -->

## The minimum code (snippet) to reproduce the issue

Example:

```
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
url='https://en.tripadvisor.com.hk/Restaurants-g294217-Hong_Kong.html'
import requests
r=requests.get(url)
soup=BeautifulSoup(r.text)
for text in soup.find_all('a'):
    print(text.get_text())
```

<!-- If you have big project hard to summarise, please upload it onto GitHub and put link here -->

## Describe the efforts you have spent on this issue
Googled similar attempts to exclude the irrelevant urls, hrefs in getting the texts of it. But cannot help excluding the other texts not needed.

Example:

### Have you Google/ Stackover flow anything?

### Do they solve or partially solve your question?

### What is the closest answer you can find?

issue.title: Feedback for Note 08
issue.body:
When I was trying to run the following piece of code:
```
df['P_ABSENT_PERSIST'].hist(bins=20)
```
I did not get a histogram. Instead, I got this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41979788/48137024-15ba1800-e2dc-11e8-88fa-a7b14024afd1.png)

issue.title: Feedback for Chapter 08
issue.body:
## Suggestions
- Histogram 
```df = pd.read_excel('nottingham.xlsx')``` When I try this code, there is module error. After system reminder, I install ```xlrd```, then it can work. I guess you can add it.

- Percentile
Maybe you can add the ```df["AVG_ENG_MATH_SCORE_10"].quantile(0.5)``` is equal to ```df["AVG_ENG_MATH_SCORE_10"].median()```, which can help us to understand the percentile better.

-  Continuous
Misspell in this sentence: For example, **```person```** measure the degree of the relationship between linearly related variables, while Spearman rank correlation is a non-parametric test. For more details

- Bonus: Better visualisation
```sns.regplot(df['P_ABSENT_PERSIST'], df['AVG_ENG_MATH_SCORE_09'])```
For this bonus, could you give more explanation why this visualisation is better than above one? Adding it in notes is alright.

- isna() & fillna()
I guess add some references or detailed explanation about this two functions will be better, it's a bit hard to understand. This[ link ](https://blog.csdn.net/lwgkzl/article/details/80948548)is useful. 

- Filter out in the charts
```s```  is not defined in your code.

## Conclusion: 
There are many new functions and concepts in this chapter, I guess a better way can help us learn it more efficiency is adding simple annotation like this ```# annotation ``` after new code.

issue.title: How to click "Next page" when scrap data by using selenium
issue.body:
## Describe your environment

* Operating system:OS
* Python version:3
* Hardware:
* Internet access:
* Jupyter notebook or not? [Y/N]:Y
* Which chapter of book?:week6

<!-- Texts appear in angle brackets like this are comments and will not show in your issue body. They are here to help you fill in this form. Feel free to remove those comments. You can also remove other texts that is irrelevant to your issue -->

## Describe your question
when I use selenium to scroll the window to turn page,  the position always went wrong and could not click the "NEXT PAGE".
Could someone help me! thanks! @hupili  @ChicoXYC 
<!-- Upload screenshot if it helps. Simply drag and drop the image in this editing window. -->

## The code 


```
from selenium import webdriver
import time
url = "https://www.jd.com/index.html"
browser = webdriver.Chrome()
browser.get(url)
keywords = browser.find_element_by_id("key").send_keys("手机\n")
time.sleep(2)

#尝试1:
#browser.execute_script("window.scrollTo(0, document.body.scrollHeight/1);")
#browser.find_element_by_class_name("pn-next").click()

#尝试2:
# height = .1
# while height < 9.9:
#     browser.execute_script("window.scrollTo(0, document.body.scrollHeight/%s);" % height)
#     next_page = browser.find_element_by_xpath("//span[@class='p-num']//a[@title='使用方向键右键也可翻到下一页哦！']")
#     if next_page:
#         next_page.click()
#         break
#     height += .1        

#尝试3:
# element = browser.find_element_by_class_name("pn-next")
# browser.execute_script("return arguments[0].scrollIntoView();", element)
# element.click()
```

issue.title: how to slice two elements under the same content when one of them may be None sometimes?
issue.body:
# Troubleshooting ## Describe your environment * Operating system: * Python version: python3 * Hardware: * Internet access: * Jupyter notebook or not? [Y/N]: Y * Which chapter of book?: ## Describe your question When scraping http://maoyan.com/board/4?offset=0, I want to slice the two elements: "release time" and "country" out respectively, but some movies show their country, some don't . for instance some are like this :

上映时间：1993-01-01

while some :

上映时间：1994-10-14(美国)

So my question is how to slice the "two" elements? btw, it seems that they belong to one string tightly.

comment.body:
@18426425 For this case, I think the format of time is fixed, with 10 character length. Therefore, we can use list slicing to separate them.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37010763/48253547-7bc0af80-e442-11e8-9f2a-fdcebbfe308c.png)

issue.title: comments on Chapter7 - [improve: better narrative/ elaboration]
issue.body:
1. If we do not define the bins when using hist() function, it seems I can not get a distribution image. So do we need to always define the bins by ourselves?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42017792/46645585-2467bf00-cbb8-11e8-97d6-b578b540ee12.png)

2. Do we need to define the key and value in mapping function? If we have vast sum of data, how could we be more convenient to clean the data?

3. I try to apply "descending=False" (it supposed to be sorting by ascending, but there is no keyword argument defined. So in sort function, we can only apply 'ascending' by using True/False right?)

4. I dont know why I cannot get a csv.file after using the to_csv format, and why should I input 'index' here? 

Thanks a lot!

issue.title: comments on Chapter7 - [improve: better narrative/ elaboration]
issue.body:
1. If we do not define the bins when using hist() function, it seems I can not get a distribution image. So do we need to always define the bins by ourselves?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42017792/46645585-2467bf00-cbb8-11e8-97d6-b578b540ee12.png)

2. Do we need to define the key and value in mapping function? If we have vast sum of data, how could we be more convenient to clean the data?

3. I try to apply "descending=False" (it supposed to be sorting by ascending, but there is no keyword argument defined. So in sort function, we can only apply 'ascending' by using True/False right?)

4. I dont know why I cannot get a csv.file after using the to_csv format, and why should I input 'index' here? 

Thanks a lot!

issue.title: Assignment 1-Data of different kinds pop up all at once in rows
issue.body:
# Troubleshooting
Different types of data (names, types, numbers of reviews, etc., as the website crawled is TripAdvisor) came up in one piece of text and in rows, stopping further attempts in ranking in rows with different columns showing different specs in cvs file. Also, irrelevant texts that should be in other parts of the site were included. Should be because of wrong coding/filtering in the previous steps but couldn't define which parts to be included.

## Describe your environment

* Operating system: MacOS 10.11.6
* Python version: 3.6.3
* Hardware: MBPR 13" 2015
* Internet access: Wi-Fi
* Jupyter notebook or not? [Y/N]:Y
* Which chapter of book?:Assignment

<!-- Texts appear in angle brackets like this are comments and will not show in your issue body. They are here to help you fill in this form. Feel free to remove those comments. You can also remove other texts that is irrelevant to your issue -->

## Describe your question
Where to look for the exact tags needed? How to ensure data came in different section to be written in columns instead of rows?

Example: I get IOError when running my script to load files.

<!-- Upload screenshot if it helps. Simply drag and drop the image in this editing window. -->

## The minimum code (snippet) to reproduce the issue

Example:

```
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
url='https://en.tripadvisor.com.hk/Restaurants-g294217-Hong_Kong.html'
import requests
r=requests.get(url)
soup=BeautifulSoup(r.text)
for text in soup.find_all('a'):
    print(text.get_text())
```

<!-- If you have big project hard to summarise, please upload it onto GitHub and put link here -->

## Describe the efforts you have spent on this issue
Googled similar attempts to exclude the irrelevant urls, hrefs in getting the texts of it. But cannot help excluding the other texts not needed.

Example:

### Have you Google/ Stackover flow anything?

### Do they solve or partially solve your question?

### What is the closest answer you can find?

comment.body:
@Wong-Ming 
Please find all elements/retaurants first, every element include all info of one restaurant.Then you can use a for loop to get the attributes you want. The following is for you consideration.
```python
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import requests
url='https://en.tripadvisor.com.hk/Restaurants-g294217-Hong_Kong.html'
r=requests.get(url)
soup=BeautifulSoup(r.text)
restaurants = []
for element in soup.find_all('div',attrs={'class':'ui_columns is-mobile'}): #find all elements first, every element include all info of one restaurant
    restaurant = {}
    restaurant['title']=element.find('div',attrs={'class':"title"}).text.strip()
    restaurant['rating']=element.find('div',attrs={'class':'rating rebrand'}).find('span',attrs={'class':'ui_bubble_rating bubble_45'})['alt']
#     restaurant['review'] = ...
#     restaurant['popIndex'] =
    restaurants.append(restaurant)
```

issue.title: How to solve the 'UnicodeEncodeError' and the messy code problem?
issue.body:
here are my codes:
```
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import csv

def scrape_onepage(purl):
    r = requests.get(purl).text
    data = BeautifulSoup(r,"html.parser")
    all_div = data.find('div',attrs={'class':"wrapper fixed"}).find_all("li")
    tittles=[]
    for i in all_div:
        tittle=[]
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"t"}).find('strong').text.strip())
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"w"}).text.strip())
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"t"}).find('a')['href'])
        tittles.append(tittle)
    return tittles
def scrape_all_pages(url):
    page_urls=[]
    comments=[]
    for i in range(1,15):  
        if i == 1:
            url = 'http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-1.html'
        else:
            url = 'http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-{}.html'.format(i)
        page_urls.append(url)
    for purl in page_urls:
        comments.extend(scrape_onepage(purl))
    return(comments)
result = scrape_all_pages('http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-1.html')


with open('cbc.csv','a',encoding='utf-8') as f:

    writer = csv.writer(f)
    header = ['titles','comment','url']
    writer.writerow(header)
    writer.writerows(result)
```

It runs ok, however, when you open the file in Excel, it goes wrong.

Before this problem,  I was soloving the unicode problem as follows:
```
with open('cbc.csv','w') as f:
    writer = csv.writer(f)
    header = ['titles','comment','url']
    writer.writerow(header)
    writer.writerows(result)
```

after excuted, it goes:

> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
> UnicodeEncodeError                        Traceback (most recent call last)
> <ipython-input-142-9921ad8beff1> in <module>()
>     35     header = ['Titles','comment','Url']
>     36     writer.writerow(header)
> ---> 37     writer.writerows(result)
> 
> UnicodeEncodeError: 'gbk' codec can't encode character '\u2022' in position 17: illegal multibyte sequence

I google it and they told me is about the decoding and encoding problem, but I tried to add a parameter'encoding='utf-8''. It still can't be open by jupyternote book which tells me the csv file is not UTF-8 encoded. And when I tried to open it with Excel, it shows messy code again.
So, how can I solve these two problem?

issue.title: How to solve the 'UnicodeEncodeError' and the messy code problem?
issue.body:
here are my codes:
```
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import csv

def scrape_onepage(purl):
    r = requests.get(purl).text
    data = BeautifulSoup(r,"html.parser")
    all_div = data.find('div',attrs={'class':"wrapper fixed"}).find_all("li")
    tittles=[]
    for i in all_div:
        tittle=[]
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"t"}).find('strong').text.strip())
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"w"}).text.strip())
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"t"}).find('a')['href'])
        tittles.append(tittle)
    return tittles
def scrape_all_pages(url):
    page_urls=[]
    comments=[]
    for i in range(1,15):  
        if i == 1:
            url = 'http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-1.html'
        else:
            url = 'http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-{}.html'.format(i)
        page_urls.append(url)
    for purl in page_urls:
        comments.extend(scrape_onepage(purl))
    return(comments)
result = scrape_all_pages('http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-1.html')


with open('cbc.csv','a',encoding='utf-8') as f:

    writer = csv.writer(f)
    header = ['titles','comment','url']
    writer.writerow(header)
    writer.writerows(result)
```

It runs ok, however, when you open the file in Excel, it goes wrong.

Before this problem,  I was soloving the unicode problem as follows:
```
with open('cbc.csv','w') as f:
    writer = csv.writer(f)
    header = ['titles','comment','url']
    writer.writerow(header)
    writer.writerows(result)
```

after excuted, it goes:

> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
> UnicodeEncodeError                        Traceback (most recent call last)
> <ipython-input-142-9921ad8beff1> in <module>()
>     35     header = ['Titles','comment','Url']
>     36     writer.writerow(header)
> ---> 37     writer.writerows(result)
> 
> UnicodeEncodeError: 'gbk' codec can't encode character '\u2022' in position 17: illegal multibyte sequence

I google it and they told me is about the decoding and encoding problem, but I tried to add a parameter'encoding='utf-8''. It still can't be open by jupyternote book which tells me the csv file is not UTF-8 encoded. And when I tried to open it with Excel, it shows messy code again.
So, how can I solve these two problem?

comment.body:
Avoid encoding error with opening csv in Excel, please check out here 👉
https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/56bc1354cdc659950b0591a06ddce3e9140ceb6b/module-csv.md#encoding-issue-about-microsoft-excel

issue.title: Some problems about turning page
issue.body:
Here is my codes. I find that when turning pages it stops at the 3rd page.  I tried a lot but could not find the reason. Thank you! @ChicoXYC 
```
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.common.exceptions import StaleElementReferenceException, NoSuchElementException
import time

def get_by_css(session, css, text=True):
    try:
        MAX_TRY = 3
        t = 0
        while t < MAX_TRY:
            t += 1
            try:
                res = session.find_element_by_css_selector(css)
            except StaleElementReferenceException:
                time.sleep(2)
                continue
            break
        if t == MAX_TRY:
            return None
    except NoSuchElementException:
        return None
    if text:
        return res.text
    return res

def get_hotels_from_browser(b):

    hotels = []
    for session in b.find_elements_by_css_selector('.sr_item.sr_item_new.sr_item_default.sr_property_block.sr_flex_layout'):
        hotel = {}
        name = get_by_css(session, 'span.sr-hotel__name')
        score = get_by_css(session, '.bui-review-score__badge')
        comments = get_by_css(session, '.bui-review-score__text')
        address = get_by_css(session, '.jq_tooltip.district_link.visited_link')
        price = get_by_css(session, '.price.availprice.no_rack_rate')
        if not price:
            price = get_by_css(session, '.price.scarcity_color')

        hotel['name'] = name
        hotel['score'] = score
        hotel['comments'] = comments
        hotel['address'] = address
        hotel['price'] = price

        hotels.append(hotel)
    return hotels

url = 'https://www.booking.com/searchresults.zh-cn.html?aid=378266&label=booking-name-IquAp*EbiLS6jPVl_he8yQS267778093594%3Apl%3Ata%3Ap1%3Ap2%3Aac%3Aap1t1%3Aneg%3Afi%3Atikwd-65526620%3Alp9061634%3Ali%3Adec%3Adm&sid=75a6a10fd83d509dc44f2bc75e94dc31&checkin_month=9&checkin_monthday=12&checkin_year=2019&checkout_month=9&checkout_monthday=13&checkout_year=2019&city=-240905&class_interval=1&dest_id=-240905&dest_type=city&from_sf=1&group_adults=2&group_children=0&label_click=undef&no_rooms=1&raw_dest_type=city&room1=A%2CA&sb_price_type=total&shw_aparth=1&slp_r_match=0&src=searchresults&srpvid=342a6023a36e0036&ss=%E5%A4%A7%E9%98%AA&ssb=empty&ssne=%E5%A4%A7%E9%98%AA&ssne_untouched=%E5%A4%A7%E9%98%AA&nflt=di%3D7322%3Bpri%3D2%3B&rsf=pri-2&lsf=pri%7C2%7C136'
browser = webdriver.Chrome()
browser.get(url)
time.sleep(2)

all_page_hotels = []
for i in range(7):
    new_hotels= get_hotels_from_browser(browser)
    all_page_hotels.extend(new_hotels)
    time.sleep(0.5)
    no_survey = get_by_css(browser, '.survey_no_button', False)
    if no_survey:
        no_survey.click()
    time.sleep(0.5)
    browser.execute_script('window.scrollTo(0, document.body.scrollHeight/1.5);')
    next_page = browser.find_element_by_css_selector('.bui-pagination__item.bui-pagination__next-arrow')

    next_page.click()

print(all_page_hotels)

```

comment.body:
@Shinonomee 
Just add a time sleep after line `for i in range(0,7)` will help to solve the problem. Its a good practice to leave a time sleep where need a period of time to load content.

```python
for i in range(7):
    time.sleep(2) #add this line
    new_hotels= get_hotels_from_browser(browser)
    all_page_hotels.extend(new_hotels)
    time.sleep(0.5)
    no_survey = get_by_css(browser, '.survey_no_button', False)
    if no_survey:
        no_survey.click()
    time.sleep(1)
    next_button = browser.find_element_by_css_selector('div.bui-pagination li.bui-pagination__item.bui-pagination__next-arrow a')
    next_button.location
    loc = next_button.location
    browser.execute_script("window.scrollTo({x}, {y});".format(**loc))
    time.sleep(2) #add this line
    next_button.click()
```

issue.title: A question about the codes to extract article url in week5 - [improve: list slicing]
issue.body:
For the example in week5 which extracts all article urls in http://initiumlab.com, all the tags including the article urls have been collected like below
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/46424907-f83ddf80-c76c-11e8-82ea-7b64b22804a7.png)

Next, we need to get the strings after 'href' (e.g.'href="../blog/20170113-Sharing-With-Friends-Versus-Strangers/"'), and the codes are as below:
```
for my_url in my_urls:
    url ='{0}{1}'.format('http://initiumlab.com',my_url['href'][2:]) #format urls
        #print(url)
    article_urls.append(url)
article_urls

```
However, I do not quite understand what `my_url['href'][2:]` means here. 'my_url['href']' seems to be a function of finding the  value through the corresponding key in a dictionary, but 'my_url' is a list element.  [2:] seems to be a function of extracting part of words in string. I feel a little bit confused.

issue.title: A question about the codes to extract article url in week5 - [improve: list slicing]
issue.body:
For the example in week5 which extracts all article urls in http://initiumlab.com, all the tags including the article urls have been collected like below
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/46424907-f83ddf80-c76c-11e8-82ea-7b64b22804a7.png)

Next, we need to get the strings after 'href' (e.g.'href="../blog/20170113-Sharing-With-Friends-Versus-Strangers/"'), and the codes are as below:
```
for my_url in my_urls:
    url ='{0}{1}'.format('http://initiumlab.com',my_url['href'][2:]) #format urls
        #print(url)
    article_urls.append(url)
article_urls

```
However, I do not quite understand what `my_url['href'][2:]` means here. 'my_url['href']' seems to be a function of finding the  value through the corresponding key in a dictionary, but 'my_url' is a list element.  [2:] seems to be a function of extracting part of words in string. I feel a little bit confused.

comment.body: Update list slicing. Please refer to our notes: https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/4910697fc6f5b32701adf1df6a593dbec4581506/notes-week-03.md#list-slicing

issue.title: Some problems about turning page
issue.body:
Here is my codes. I find that when turning pages it stops at the 3rd page.  I tried a lot but could not find the reason. Thank you! @ChicoXYC 
```
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.common.exceptions import StaleElementReferenceException, NoSuchElementException
import time

def get_by_css(session, css, text=True):
    try:
        MAX_TRY = 3
        t = 0
        while t < MAX_TRY:
            t += 1
            try:
                res = session.find_element_by_css_selector(css)
            except StaleElementReferenceException:
                time.sleep(2)
                continue
            break
        if t == MAX_TRY:
            return None
    except NoSuchElementException:
        return None
    if text:
        return res.text
    return res

def get_hotels_from_browser(b):

    hotels = []
    for session in b.find_elements_by_css_selector('.sr_item.sr_item_new.sr_item_default.sr_property_block.sr_flex_layout'):
        hotel = {}
        name = get_by_css(session, 'span.sr-hotel__name')
        score = get_by_css(session, '.bui-review-score__badge')
        comments = get_by_css(session, '.bui-review-score__text')
        address = get_by_css(session, '.jq_tooltip.district_link.visited_link')
        price = get_by_css(session, '.price.availprice.no_rack_rate')
        if not price:
            price = get_by_css(session, '.price.scarcity_color')

        hotel['name'] = name
        hotel['score'] = score
        hotel['comments'] = comments
        hotel['address'] = address
        hotel['price'] = price

url = 'https://www.booking.com/searchresults.zh-cn.html?aid=378266&label=booking-name-IquAp*EbiLS6jPVl_he8yQS267778093594%3Apl%3Ata%3Ap1%3Ap2%3Aac%3Aap1t1%3Aneg%3Afi%3Atikwd-65526620%3Alp9061634%3Ali%3Adec%3Adm&sid=75a6a10fd83d509dc44f2bc75e94dc31&checkin_month=9&checkin_monthday=12&checkin_year=2019&checkout_month=9&checkout_monthday=13&checkout_year=2019&city=-240905&class_interval=1&dest_id=-240905&dest_type=city&from_sf=1&group_adults=2&group_children=0&label_click=undef&no_rooms=1&raw_dest_type=city&room1=A%2CA&sb_price_type=total&shw_aparth=1&slp_r_match=0&src=searchresults&srpvid=342a6023a36e0036&ss=%E5%A4%A7%E9%98%AA&ssb=empty&ssne=%E5%A4%A7%E9%98%AA&ssne_untouched=%E5%A4%A7%E9%98%AA&nflt=di%3D7322%3Bpri%3D2%3B&rsf=pri-2&lsf=pri%7C2%7C136'
browser = webdriver.Chrome()
browser.get(url)
time.sleep(2)

all_page_hotels = []
for i in range(7):
    new_hotels= get_hotels_from_browser(browser)
    all_page_hotels.extend(new_hotels)
    time.sleep(0.5)
    no_survey = get_by_css(browser, '.survey_no_button', False)
    if no_survey:
        no_survey.click()
    time.sleep(0.5)
    browser.execute_script('window.scrollTo(0, document.body.scrollHeight/1.5);')
    next_page = browser.find_element_by_css_selector('.bui-pagination__item.bui-pagination__next-arrow')

    next_page.click()

print(all_page_hotels)

```

comment.body: @Shinonomee that's probably because you don't match the `precise click button`. please refer here:https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/module-selenium.md#find-elements-by-css-selector

Could someone help me! thanks! @hupili  @ChicoXYC

issue.title: Ch6 Feedbacks - [improve: partial link & scroll]
issue.body:
- In this section [#advanced-all-pages](https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/notes-week-06.md#advanced-all-pages)
the second line from the bottom `df = pd.DataFrame(articles)` may should be `df = pd.DataFrame(all_page_articles)`, otherwise the variable `articles` cannot be found.

- In this section [#navigating](https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/notes-week-06.md#navigating)
The introduction words ’You can doing a lot of interactive things with the webpage... ‘ should be 'You can do ...'
The line from the bottom `link = browser.find_element_by_link_text('GitHub - hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook')` could use `find_element_by_partial_link_text` instead, in case the text of link cannot be displayed completely on some small screens like mine:(

issue.title: Ch6 Feedbacks - [improve: partial link & scroll]
issue.body:
- In this section [#advanced-all-pages](https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/notes-week-06.md#advanced-all-pages)
the second line from the bottom `df = pd.DataFrame(articles)` may should be `df = pd.DataFrame(all_page_articles)`, otherwise the variable `articles` cannot be found.

- In this section [#navigating](https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/notes-week-06.md#navigating)
The introduction words ’You can doing a lot of interactive things with the webpage... ‘ should be 'You can do ...'
The line from the bottom `link = browser.find_element_by_link_text('GitHub - hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook')` could use `find_element_by_partial_link_text` instead, in case the text of link cannot be displayed completely on some small screens like mine:(

comment.body:
* merged into notes: Window scroll methods: https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/notes-week-06.md#scroll-down-certain-element
* merged into FAQs: Takeaways on `select_element_by_css_selector`: https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/module-selenium.md#find-elements-by-css-selector

issue.title: issues about installing jupyter in CVA517
issue.body: [Here](https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/module-jupyter.md) are the instruction of how to install jupyter generally, we typing following command to create virtual environment then install all dependencies and modules. But in lab, there are some problem: ``` pyvenv venv source venv/bin/activate pip3 install jupyter ``` You will get the error of upgrade your `pip` version during install jupyter, just copy the command. ``` pip install --upgrade pip ``` Then, install jupyter, open the jupyter notebook ``` pip3 install jupyter jupyter notebook ``` then you will encounter another problem, whenever you execute what, it shows its in running and there is a sign saying that `kernel starting, please wait...` The reason can be found in the terminal that when you install jupyter, there is an red line saying: ``` ipython 7.0.1 has requirement prompt-toolkit<2.1.0,>=2.0.0, but you'll have prompt-toolkit 1.0.15 which is incompatible. ``` In oder to solve this, there is two solutions which can be found in [jupyter_kernel issue#158](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter_console/issues/158) solution 1: `pip install 'ipykernel<5.0.0' ` solution 2: first downgraded ipython `pip install -U ipython==6.5.0`, then prompt-tookit `pip install -U prompt-toolkit==1.0.15` Finally, open jupyter notebook, type something to test, it should work now!

issue.title: issues about installing jupyter in CVA517
issue.body: [Here](https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/module-jupyter.md) are the instruction of how to install jupyter generally, we typing following command to create virtual environment then install all dependencies and modules. But in lab, there are some problem: ``` pyvenv venv source venv/bin/activate pip3 install jupyter ``` You will get the error of upgrade your `pip` version during install jupyter, just copy the command. ``` pip install --upgrade pip ``` Then, install jupyter, open the jupyter notebook ``` pip3 install jupyter jupyter notebook ``` then you will encounter another problem, whenever you execute what, it shows its in running and there is a sign saying that `kernel starting, please wait...` The reason can be found in the terminal that when you install jupyter, there is an red line saying: ``` ipython 7.0.1 has requirement prompt-toolkit<2.1.0,>=2.0.0, but you'll have prompt-toolkit 1.0.15 which is incompatible. ``` In oder to solve this, there is two solutions which can be found in [jupyter_kernel issue#158](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter_console/issues/158) solution 1: `pip install 'ipykernel<5.0.0' ` solution 2: first downgraded ipython `pip install -U ipython==6.5.0`, then prompt-tookit `pip install -U prompt-toolkit==1.0.15` Finally, open jupyter notebook, type something to test, it should work now!

comment.body: Merged into FAQs. Please refer here: https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/module-jupyter.md#set-jupyter-environment-in-cva517

issue.title: I cannot find required number in the tag.
issue.body: * Operating system:Mac os * Python version:py3 * Hardware:mac pro * Internet access:wifi * Jupyter notebook or not? [Y/N]:y * Which chapter of book?:5 I cannot find required number in the tag. My dataset is about to scrape the top20 popular original works in main media genres on the AO3(https://archiveofourown.org/media). The number of fan work cannot to be scraped since it is not in the tag. data fields are as bellows genre - String. e.g.Anime & Manga fanwork number - Int.e.g.36 original works name - String.e.g Haikyuu!! my code is as bellows: import requests from bs4 import BeautifulSoup r = requests.get('https://archiveofourown.org/media') html_str = r.text #get the content of the request data = BeautifulSoup(html_str,"html.parser") my_h1 = data.find('h1') # 查找网页主页标题 my_title = my_h1.text print(my_title.strip()) my_h2 = data.find('h2') # 查找网页主页副标题 my_title2 = my_h2.text print(my_title2.strip()) my_bookname=data.find_all('a')#查找各书名 for tag in my_bookname: print (tag.text) headers = ['bookname','num'] from csv import* import csv with open('list.csv','w',newline='')as f: f_csv=csv.writer(f) if(headers): f_csv.writerow(headers) if(tag.text): f_csv.writerows(tag.text) ## Describe the efforts you have spent on this issue This is the structure of Douban and the number of viewers is in the tag. ![wechatimg1866](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42727192/48042753-12c90580-e1be-11e8-884b-c42d3322797b.png) I don't know if it is the problem of ao3 or I just get it wrong.hope you can help me.Thank you!

comment.body:
@Rita0719  You can find the number is in the `li` tag. Therefore you can use `li.text` to get the number. Since the book title also in the `li` tag. You can use `split()` function to separate those two elements and use `list slicing` to get the number.

Apart from the finding numbers. Its strongly suggested the `elements first` method to loacate the data you are interested in. 

Like, you should find the session first. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37010763/48045747-8d991d00-e1cc-11e8-81c4-befce4a0c439.png)

And in each session, you can use `for loop` to get 4-5 books. And find title, review number in each book. This way is more logical clearly instead of directly find the all books title. You can refer to the following codes.

```python
book_session = data.find_all('li', attrs={'class':"medium listbox group"})
books=[]
for session in book_session:
    elements = session.find_all('li')    
    for element in elements:
        book = {}
        book['name'] = element.find('a').text
        book['reviews'] = element.text.strip().split('\n')[-1].strip()
        books.append(book)
```

issue.title: The step to get "twitter API" (week04)
issue.body:
* Which chapter of book:week04

## Preparation：Twitter Account （highly recommend to use **Gmail Account** to Sign up!）
## Step 1
Go to https://apps.twitter.com/app/new and click 'Apply for a developer account'.
## Step 2
Choose “Personal use” & Enter your desired Application Name, Primary country (hk) and so on.
**_The most important is_** : Describe in your own words what you are buiding

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42435100/46203467-6e48dd80-c34c-11e8-8f84-d30310b0d008.png)

you have to answer each question as detailed as possible. the following is an example:

**1. I’m using Twitter’s APIs to practice my data collection and analysis skills in the Big Data Analysis course. I am currently a postgraduate student in Hong Kong Baptist University, majoring in Communication, and normally collect users comment data for mass communication study research.
2. As for the methods and techniques I plan to conduct, here is our course GitHub open book. You can take it as reference. https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/notes-week-04.md#use-api-via-function-calls-to-other-modules-packages
3. I only use it to do data collection practice, will not use case to tweeting, retweeting or liking content.
4. Tweets will be displayed on our final project presentation for academic use.
5. Finally, I will comply with the Policies of twitter. 
I am looking forward to your favorable reply.**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42435100/46203968-1ca15280-c34e-11e8-8db7-d8fc00a60ddf.png)

and then, submit your application! ->verify your email

and then, your application may under review or! jump to a new page :
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42435100/46204207-faf49b00-c34e-11e8-9fa8-336e5ddb5da1.png)

issue.title: Ch6 Feedbacks - [improve: partial link & scroll]
issue.body:
- In this section [#advanced-all-pages](https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/notes-week-06.md#advanced-all-pages)
the second line from the bottom `df = pd.DataFrame(articles)` may should be `df = pd.DataFrame(all_page_articles)`, otherwise the variable `articles` cannot be found.

- In this section [#navigating](https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/notes-week-06.md#navigating)
The introduction words ’You can doing a lot of interactive things with the webpage... ‘ should be 'You can do ...'
The line from the bottom `link = browser.find_element_by_link_text('GitHub - hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook')` could use `find_element_by_partial_link_text` instead, in case the text of link cannot be displayed completely on some small screens like mine:(

comment.body: @hupili Okay

issue.title: A question about Booking scraping
issue.body:
from selenium import webdriver

browser = webdriver.Chrome()
browser.get('https://www.booking.com/searchresults.zh-cn.html?aid=378266&label=booking-name-IquAp*EbiLS6jPVl_he8yQS267778093594%3Apl%3Ata%3Ap1%3Ap2%3Aac%3Aap1t1%3Aneg%3Afi%3Atikwd-65526620%3Alp9061634%3Ali%3Adec%3Adm&sid=75a6a10fd83d509dc44f2bc75e94dc31&checkin_month=9&checkin_monthday=12&checkin_year=2019&checkout_month=9&checkout_monthday=13&checkout_year=2019&city=-240905&class_interval=1&dest_id=-240905&dest_type=city&from_sf=1&group_adults=2&group_children=0&label_click=undef&no_rooms=1&raw_dest_type=city&room1=A%2CA&sb_price_type=total&shw_aparth=1&slp_r_match=0&src=searchresults&srpvid=342a6023a36e0036&ss=%E5%A4%A7%E9%98%AA&ssb=empty&ssne=%E5%A4%A7%E9%98%AA&ssne_untouched=%E5%A4%A7%E9%98%AA&nflt=di%3D7322%3Bpri%3D2%3B&rsf=pri-2&lsf=pri%7C2%7C136')

hotels = []
for session in browser.find_elements_by_css_selector('#hotellist_inner.hotellist sr_double_search'):
    hotel = {}
    n = session.find_element_by_css_selector('span.sr-hotel__name')
    hotel['name'] = n.text
    hotel['score'] = session.find_element_by_css_selector('div.bui-review-score__badge').text
    hotels.append(hotel)
hotels

**I  use the selenium to scrape the information on Booking, but the output is [ ].  I got no error message , just the empty [ ]. Could someone find is there anything wrong with it? Thank you!**
